choice1.text: Let Ms. Jones know that participation is entirely voluntary.
choice1.tip: Not the worst response. What else can you say to Mrs. Jones to facilitate a home visit?

choice2.text: Remind Ms. Jones that she already agreed to the appointment.
choice2.tip: Not a good response! How might you deliver this message differently?

choice3.text: Let Ms. Jones know about the benefits of your program.
choice3.tip: Good!  This response is less likely to elicit a defensive response from the client while continuing to allow her a choice to participate.

choice4.text: Allow Ms. Jones more time to think about it and call her back later.
choice4.tip: Not the worst response. What else can you say to Mrs. Jones to facilitate a home visit?

choice1.text: Ask Ms. Jones where she prefers to sit.
choice1.tip: Not the worst response. Are there any potential problems with this?

choice2.text: Request a quiet area, such as a bedroom.
choice2.tip: Not a good response! Why might it not be appropriate to meet a client in a bedroom?

choice3.text: Although in a common area, suggest the kitchen or dining room table.
choice3.tip: Good!  This response allows the case manager to meet in a neutral part of the home away from distractions while having an area to take notes.
